comment.author: 26220432@N06
comment._content: Cool picture but as far as I know this is quite "common" in old pictures. Often said to be a spirit it really came from using the same printinsheet (I don't know the english name for this) for several shots to save costs. There'd be a bit of ink left on the sheet that would then be 'picked up' as another picture was put over it which created the "ghost". (So the ghost is really just a person from a previous picture)

comment.author: 22390815@N05
comment._content:
It is a double exposure, I had an old camera I use to like to use. The film had to be advanced by a hand crank.  sometimes if I forgot to advance it, the first picture would look spooky and superimpose itself over the next picture(s).   I would do it on purpose, but now I can't buy the film or get it developed.   I got the idea from this:
I have one picture of my mom and a giant rabbit.  The rabbit was taken first, then a picture of my mother, she was a child then, circa 1930.  It did look like a giant ghost rabbit and a child.

comment.author: 81392520@N00
comment._content: It was certainly intentional - spirit photos were easy to fake and quite popular back in the spiritualism days. There was a mad craze for them, though they look so glaringly obvious now.

comment.author: 21061284@N05
comment._content: Search William Hope. He was one of the premiere spirit photographers of the early Twentieth Century and was considered by believers and supporters to be a true master of the art of producing spirits on ordinary photographic plates. To others, he was a clever trickster and while he had more than his share of detractors, he was often accused of fraud but was never caught at it -- thanks to the controversy that surrounded the main attempt to expose him.

comment.author: 28973849@N07
comment._content: exposures then took a really long time, so if the photograph took 10 minutes to expose, for example, someone else could make a ghost like appearance if they wandered around in the picture for like 3 minutes...

comment.author: 23352562@N06
comment._content: I have to agree with a previous comment that, if this were a true double exposure, you would have seen more of the ghostly person's body and the face wouldn't have been as bright.  I have two old stereographs from approximately 1851 which show the double-exposure technique used in a 3D image, so photographers certainly knew about it then.  But I would say this image was "burned in" in the darkroom, using an image of a man's face (masked off) and then some wispy areas lightened for effect.

comment.author: 49841746@N03
comment._content: If you look at the man in the backgroung, he is much larger in porportion to the man sitting down. I think this image most likely was acheived by first exposing the film with the man in sitting down, then asking him to leave. Next I think they moved the camera closer to the curtain and exposed the same frame of film with the man with the curtain up around his head. At least that is how I would do it without the use of photoshop.
